introduction: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
text:
• The Indus Valley Civilization (3300–1300 BCE) was located in the region of modern-day Pakistan and northwest India.
• This civilization boasted carefully planned cities such as Mohenjo-daro and Harappa.
• Archaeologists discovered standardized weights and measures there, implying a sophisticated trade system.
• The civilization’s script remains undeciphered, leaving many questions unanswered.
• Evidence suggests advanced drainage and sewage networks in these cities.
question: The student wants to emphasize the Indus Valley Civilization’s technological and organizational sophistication. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?
A: Mohenjo-daro and Harappa were two of the major urban centers of the Indus Valley Civilization.
B: Archaeologists have been unable to decipher the script left behind by the Indus Valley Civilization.
C: The Indus cities featured advanced drainage systems and employed standardized weights and measures, indicating high levels of planning and organization.
D: The Indus Valley region is now part of modern-day Pakistan and northwest India.
explanation: Choice C focuses on two key pieces of evidence—standardized measures and sophisticated drainage—that show the civilization’s high degree of technological and organizational development.
